DOC.HEAD: Six Beheaded in Saudi Arabia For Drug Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: Six people convicted of drug smuggling were beheaded in public Friday in the northeastern city of Arar, the government said. The six _ three Saudi Arabians, a Syrian, a Jordanian and a Turk _ were convicted by Islamic courts of smuggling hashish into the kingdom, the Interior Ministry said. Capital punishment for drug importing was introduced by the kingdom in recent years in an attempt to curb drug smuggling, which has been spreading rapidly since the oil bonanza years in Saudi Arabia and the rest of the region. The theocratic kingdom rules by the Koran, which prescribes beheading for murder, stoning for adultery and hand cutting for theft. Moslem theologians ruled that capital punishment was applicable to drug smugglers because beheading covered those who ``spread corruption on the face of the Earth.'' About a dozen other drug smugglers have been beheaded this year, most of them Pakistani nationals. Beheadings are usually carried out in public squares opposite mosques following the Friday prayers, and sometimes the bodies are hung on crossed beams to act as a deterrent.
